panama.form
Class FormData

java.lang.Object
  panama.form.FormData

public class FormData
extends java.lang.Object

This class represents the data contained in the form passed to the constructor. The form itself is just a description of a form and it's field and resides in the application scope. It must never be changed by this class. This FormData class contains the data and normally resides in request or session scope. Validation is done during getting the values from the form. This class does not support Multipart Fileuploads, instead, please use the FileItem methods of Context class to access uploaded files. This class provides getters for common types. On error (cast etc.) they simply return null For how to get values of other types

Author:
Ridcully
See Also:
getValue(String), getValues(String)

Constructor Detail

FormData

public FormData(Form form)
Invokes FormData(Form, Map) with null for inputMap

Parameters:
form -

FormData

public FormData(Form form,
                java.util.Map inputMap)
Presets input for all boolean fields with FALSE (as normally these are used for checkboxes and we do not get values for unchecked checkboxes) before applying the passed inputMap. If you do not want this behaviour, you can call setInput(field, null) afterwards for the fields you do not want to have FALSE set as input (e.g. if you have a Boolean field and some sort of threeway input with TRUE, FALSE and "don't care")

Parameters:
form -
inputMap -
Method Detail

setInput

public void setInput(java.util.Map inputMap)
Sets the form's input from the specified map. Does not touch values of fields not in map (useful if there are more form-fields than parameters from request (e.g. a wizard could have 1 large form across several pages, each of which gives just some values) The keys of the parameters map are the names of the fields The values of the map may be string, object, string[] or object[] String[] arrays as coming from request (even if there's only one value)

Parameters:
inputMap -
See Also:
setInput(String, Object)

setInput

public void setInput(java.lang.Object bean)
Sets the form's input from the specified bean.

Parameters:
bean - The bean from which the values are fetched

setInput

public void setInput(java.lang.String fieldName,
                     java.lang.Object value)
Sets the input value for one field If value is an object or array of objects, the objects are converted to strings using the valueToString method of the field Note, that the value is not validated here and now, but just when it is fetched using one of the get[String|Integer|...]() or the getValue() or getValues() methods.

Parameters:
fieldName -
value - may be single string or object or an array of strings or objects

applyTo

public void applyTo(java.lang.Object bean)
Applies current input-data to the specified bean. The field names must match the property names for this method to work as expected. If unknown properties are encountered, _no_ values are set (an error message is logged at debug-level) If wrong property-types are encountered, or fields are missing for property-names a message is logged at debug-level.

Parameters:
bean - The bean, the current input-data will be applied to.

applyTo

public void applyTo(java.lang.Object bean,
                    java.lang.String... properties)
Applies current input-data to the specified properties of the specified bean. The field names must match the property names for this method to work as expected. If unknown properties are encountered, _no_ values are set (an error message is logged at debug-level) If wrong property-types are encountered, or fields are missing for property-names a message is logged at debug-level.

Parameters:
bean - The bean, the input should be applied to.
properties - the properties to be set

applyTo

public void applyTo(java.lang.Object bean,
                    int method,
                    java.lang.String... properties)
Applies current input-data to the specified or all but the properties of the specified bean. The field names must match the property names for this method to work as expected. If unknown properties are encountered, _no_ values are set (an error message is logged at debug-level) If wrong property-types are encountered, or fields are missing for property-names a message is logged at debug-level. If a property is annotated as javax.persistence.Version it is NOT set!

Parameters:
bean - The bean, the input should be applied to.
properties - the properties to be set or to be skipped, depending on method
method - wether to set the specified or all _but_ the specified properties. Value should be one of Form.INCLUDE_PROPERTIES or Form.EXCLUDE_PROPERTIES

get

public java.lang.Object get(java.lang.String fieldName)
Gets the original input for the specified field. Useful to fill a field where validation failed. Intentionally named just get() as this allows to use $formdata.fieldName in velocity which invokes this method as form.get('fieldName') If (as it is most of the time) there is just one value, the array is flattened

Parameters:
fieldName -
Returns:
the original input

getInput

public java.util.Map getInput()
Provides a copy of the input map. To be used in JSPs with JSTL as ${formdata.input["fieldName"]}

getInput

public java.lang.Object[] getInput(java.lang.String fieldName)
Gets the original input for the specified field. This method does not flatten the input array if there's only one value. Useful if you need to iterate over the input, regardless whether it has one or more values.

Parameters:
fieldName -
Returns:
the original input

getErrors

public java.util.Map<java.lang.String,ValidatorException> getErrors()
Gets map of errors, key == fieldname, value = ValidatorException

Returns:
A map of errors or an empty map

hasErrors

public boolean hasErrors()
Checks if there are errors

Returns:
true if there are errors, false otherwise
